title: Imobilidade tônica : um fenômeno clínico pouco conhecido com forte imapcto no trnastorno de estress pós-traumático

abstract: presente tese é composta por uma compilação de três artigos cujo tema central é a imobilidade tônica (IT). Considerada uma das últimas estratégias de defesa frente a uma ameaça extrema, a IT é um fenômeno prevalente que confere gravidade e má resposta ao tratamento no transtorno de estresse pós-traumático (TEPT). Apesar de sua relevância como marcador clínico do TEPT, a IT é ainda um fenômeno negligenciado tanto na prática clínica quanto científica. Através de uma revisão integrativa da literatura, exploramos os aspectos conceituais, clínicos e legais relacionados à IT em vítimas de estupro - imobilidade tônica induzida pelo estupro. No segundo estudo, discutimos a relevância clínica da IT pós-traumática relacionada à revivescência do evento traumático, podendo contribuir para a gravidade e cronicidade do TEPT. Sugerimos a inclusão da IT em futuras revisões do DSM, sendo listada como um Critério B2 (flashback) e B5 (reatividade fisiológica). Por último, num estudo transversal, investigamos o impacto das reações peritraumáticas - imobilidade tônica e dissociação - na qualidade de vida (QV) em uma amostra ambulatorial brasileira com TEPT. Demonstramos que a gravidade da IT está associada à piora da QV nos domínios psicológico e ambiental. Nenhuma das reações peritraumáticas interferiu nos domínios físico e social da QV. Dessa forma, ampliamos o estudo sobre as reações peritraumáticas e seus diferentes desfechos clínicos relacionados ao TEPT.

Considered a last -ditch defense strategy in the face of an extreme threat , TI is a prevalent phenomenon that results in severity and poor treatment response in post -traumatic s tress disorder (PTSD). Despite its relevance as a clinical marker of PTSD, TI i s still a neglected phenomenon in clinical practice and research. We explo red the conceptual, clinical, and l egal aspects related to TI in rape victims – rape induced - tonic imm obility through an integrative literature review. In the second study, we discu ssed the clinical relevance of post -traumatic TI related to the re -experie ncing of the traumat ic event, which may contribute to PTSD severity and chronicity. We sugge sted the in clusion of TI in future DSM reviews, being listed as Criterion B2 (flashback) a nd B5 (physiological reactivity). Finally, in a cross - sectional study, we investigated the imp act of peritrau matic reactions - tonic immobili ty and dissociation - in the quality of life (QoL) in a sample of Brazilian PTSD outpatients. We demonstrated that the TI`s severity negatively affected the psychological and environmental domains of QoL. None of the peritra umatic reactions interfered in t he physical and social do mains of Qo L. In this way, we expanded the knowledge about the peritraumatic reactions and their different clinical outcomes related to PTSD.

1.2 REFERENCIAL TEÓRICO

A imo bilidade tô nica é um fenômeno intrigant e, bem co nhecido e documenta do no mundo animal . Trata -se de u ma resposta inata e involuntária frente a uma grave ameaça à integrida de fís ica e a uma percepção d e inescapabilidade, mesmo na aus ência do contat o físico c om o predad or. Caract eriza -se por um es tado reversível de inibição motora e fônica, h ipertonicidade muscular, tremores , fechamento intermi tente d os olhos, olhar desfocado , anal gesia e rela tiva falta de responsividade ao meio ( RATNE R, 1967), apesa r da prese rvação da monitorizaçã o ambiental . A c onsciência e a memória para o evento estão preservadas (MARX et al., 2008). Tamb ém podem estar presente s dimi nuição da temperatura corpora l, alteraçõe s do ritmo cardíaco, aumento da frequência respira tória e alt erações no eletroc ardiograma ( CANTOR , 2009). D ependend o da espécie e das c ircunstâncias, a imobilidade tôni ca pode durar de a lguns segundos a muitas horas , com início e fim abruptos ( MARX et al., 2008).

É considerada como uma das última s etapa s da cascata defensiva contra um predador, conhecida s como congelam ento, fuga, luta e imobilidade tônica (KOZLOWSKA et al, 2015; RATNER, 1967). Diante da crescente proximi dade entre a presa e o p redador e da ausência d e possibilidade de fuga , com o a umento da ameaça à integr idade , a resposta esperada é a de imobi lidade tônica (RATNER, 1967 ). De fato, essa r eação involuntária ocorre como um último recurso de defesa frente a sit uações de grave amea ça à sobrevi vência, quando há uma percepção de inescapabilidade ou possibilidade de vencer uma luta; ou ainda em contato físico com o predador . Na evolução, é uma es tratégia altamente conservada , adaptativa, que pode aume ntar as chances de sobrevivência e reduzir a ag ressi vidade do predador (KOZLOWSKA et al, 2015; RATNER, 1967). Encontr a-se presente em um grande núm ero de diferentes espécie s dos princi pais grupos taxo nômicos, tais c omo insetos , peix es, crustáceos, anfíbios, répteis, pássaros e mamíferos (KOZLOWSKA Embora amplame nte documenta da em a nimais, soment e nos últimos anos tem havido um interesse para o seu melhor entendi mento em human os, especi almente quando ocorre durante ou log o após u m event o traumático -

imob ilidade tônica peritraumátic a (MARX et al. , 2008). Em 1979, Suarez e Gall up foram os primeiro s a questionarem as semelhanças entre a imob ilidade tônic a em animais e a paralisi a induzida pelo estupr o. Basearam -se nas descr ições de mulher es vítimas de estup ro, tais como " meu corpo ficou absolutamen te rígido" e "senti meu c orpo pa ralisado”. Verificar am que quase todos os elementos associados à imobilidade tônica em animais estavam presentes durante o estu pro, incluindo medo, contato físico e percepção de inescap abilidade .

Apesa r da importância desta s descrições, somente após mais de uma década a imob ilidade tôn ica foi investigada pela primeira vez de modo mais sistemátic o em vítimas de abus o sexual . Os au tores categorizaram a intensidade em que as vítimas “conge laram” e se sentiram incapazes de se mover , apesar de não contidas, durante a agres são sexual (GALLIANO et al., 1 993). Mais tarde, Heidt, Marx e Forsyth (2005) identificaram que as mu lheres que sofr iam violência sexual com pene tração vaginal referiam mai s imobilidade do que aquelas sem p enetra ção. A escala ut ilizada nesse e studo foi a Escala de Imobilidade Tôni ca (TIS) (FORSYTH et al. , 2000), desenvolvida para ava liar a intensidade de IT em mulheres expostas à violência sexual. Mais tar de, a estrutura fat orial do TIS f oi verificada numa amostra de mulheres vítimas de trauma sexual (FUSÉ et al., 2 007) e numa amos tra epidemiológica exposta a múltiplos event os traumát icos em homens e mulhe res (REICHENHEI M et al., 2014). Foi uma etapa import ante para a pesquis as clínica s mais sistemátic as, explorando a IT em amostras epidemiológi cas expostas a variado s eventos traumá ticos ( HAGENAARS , 2016; KALAF et al., 201 5, 2017). Em hu manos, a imobilida de tônica é correlacionada a uma ampla variedade de eventos traumáticos , embora tenha sido inicialmente associada ao trauma sexual (BRACH A, 2004; MA SER; GALLUP, 1977; LEACH , 2004 ). Recentemente, essa reação foi avaliada em pesquisas clíni cas com diferentes amostras , demo nstrando a sua i mportância como marca dor clínico do TEPT . Estudos retr ospectivos utilizand o instrumento s psicomé tricos foram realizados em mulheres v ítima s de agre ssão sexu al (BOVIN et al., 2008; HEIDT ; MARX ; FORSYTH, 2005.; HUMPHREYS et al. , 2010), estuda ntes do sexo femi nino e ma sculin o exp ostos a diferentes tipos de traum a (ABRAMS et al., 2009; BADOS ; TORIBIO ; GARCIA -GRAU , 2008 ; PORTUGA L et al., 2012) e am ostras mistas com pacientes com TEPT se cundá rio a
violência urbana (FISZMAN et al, 20 08; HAGENAARS, 2016; HAGENAARS, M.A. ; HAGENAARS, J.A. P., 2020; LIMA et al., 2010; ROC HA-REGO et al., 2009 ).
1.2.1 Imobilidade tônica peritra umática

Foi de monstrado que a imobilid ade tônica peritra umát ica é uma importante preditora de oco rrência de me mória s intrusivas ( HAGENAARS ; PUTMA N, 201 1), do desenv olvimento de sint omatolo gia pós -traumática ( BOVIN et al., 2008; HAGENAARS , 2016; HUMPHREYS et al., 2010; KALAF et al., 2015; MAIA et al., 2015; MÖLLER ; SÖNDERGAARD ; HELSTRÖM, 2017 ; PORTU GAL et al., 2012; ROC HA-REGO et al, 2009), de gravidade d e TEPT ( FISZMAN et al., 2008; MAIA et al., 2015 ; ROCHA -REGO et al., 2 009) e má resposta ao tratamento farmacológico (BADOS ; PERO, 2015; FISZMA N et al. , 2008; LIMA et al., 201 0). Para ap oiar a existência de imobilidade tô nica e m humanos , seus correlatos b iológicos for am regist rados durant e situações ex periment ais qu e env olviam medo intenso . Através de uma plataforma de força, correla cionaram a im obilidad e tônica a uma área reduzida de oscilação corporal, acompanhad a de um ritmo cardíaco acelerado e reduzida variabilida de da fre quência card íaca (VOLCHAN et al., 2011). Em u ma am ostra mista represent ativa da população geral, nosso grupo ampliou os estudo s sobre a imobilida de tôni ca peritraumática . Demonstramo s: 1) a associ ação entre a inte nsidade dos sin tomas de IT peritra umática e a presença de TEPT, sendo que os participantes com TEPT pontuaram mais do que o dobro na Escala de Imobilidade T ônica (TIS); 2) a relação entre IT peritra umática e o sexo feminino , com uma média de escores d a TIS de quase quatro pon tos a mais em comparação ao sexo masculino (KALAF et al., 2015); 3) a IT peritra umática ocorreu em diferent es tipos de trauma, tendo uma ma ior ass ociação com os traum as sexuais. Os escores da TIS foram quase duas ve zes maiores no a buso s exual na infância e na violência sexual em adult os, m esmo controlando p ara se xo e escolaridade. Além disso, quando exploramos o contrár io, a ausência de IT nos indivíduos expostos a diferent es tipos de trauma , encontramos u ma menor proporção de ausência de IT naqueles com trauma sexual (KALAF et al., 201 7). Dessa forma, n uma amostra epidemiológica , concluímos que a imobilidade tônica

peritraumática ocor reu em diversos tipos de eventos traumáticos, estando especialmente assoc iada ao TEPT, ao s exo femi nino e aos traumas sexuais na infância e em adultos (KALA F et al. , 2015; 2017) .
1.2.2 Imobilidade tôn ica pós-traum ática

Tradi cionalmen te de scrita como um fenômeno peritraum ático , a IT também pode ocorrer de modo recorre nte no per íodo pós-traum ático, geralmente d eflagrada por pistas relacionadas ao evento traumá tico. De fato, é possí vel que a cascata defensiva original seja ativada pela exposiç ão a lembretes re lacionados ao evento traumátic o, e aqueles indivíduos que resp onderam co m IT peritraum ática têm uma maior propensão a reagi rem novamente com IT pós-traumática (FRAGKA KI et al., 2016; HAGENAARS ; STINS ; ROELOF S, 2012 ). E esse fenômeno não é incomum , apesar d o seu papel adaptativo ser menos e vidente .

Recentemen te, verificou -se qu e mais de 70% dos indivíduos com TEPT crônic o reportaram ter imobilidade tônica de modo rec orrente, como parte da sintomat ologia pós -traumática , sendo de intensidade moderada a extrema (KLEINE et al., 2018 ). Além d isso, a IT pós-traumátic a foi cons iderada uma m ediador a ent re a IT peritra umática e a gravid ade do s sintomas do TEP T (KLEIN E et al., 2018). É poss ível que a presença e gravidade d os sintomas relacion ados à IT recorrente possam potencializar o desenvolv imento de memóri as intru sivas (HAGENA ARS; PUTMAN, 2011; KUILING ; KLAASSEN ; HAGENAARS, 2019 ) e a gravidade dos sinto mas do TEPT (ABRAMS et al., 2009; BOVIN et al., 2008 ; DE KLEINE , HAGENA ARS, VAN MINNE N, 2018 ; HUMPHREYS et al., 20 10; SCHAUER ; ELBERT , 2010 ). Diante da relevância da IT p ós-traumáti ca, LLOYD et al. (2019) dese nvolveram uma escala específica para explor ar esse fen ômeno - “Scale for Tonic imm obility Occur ring Post -trauma ” (STOP) , ratificando a n ecessidade de mais estudo s nessa área.

A imobil idade tônica pós -traumática pode ser co nsiderada um sintom a de revivescência , e um pos sível marcado r de gravidade e cronici dade do TEPT (DE KLEINE ; HAGEN AARS; VAN MINNE N, 2018 ). Um dos mecanism os prováveis para essas associações é a sobrecarga e o estresse crôni co relacionados à ativaçã o

recorrente da cascata defensiva em resposta a pistas ou lembranças relacionadas ao evento traumático , cont ribuindo para sintomatologia p ós-traumática (DE KLEINE ; HAGENA ARS; VAN MINNE N, 2018; ROELOFS et al., 2017) . Em futuras revisões dos sistemas internacionais d e classificação e diagnóst ico de transto rnos mentais , sugerimos a inclus ão da IT pós-traumática como um sintoma de revivescênci a do TEPT , sendo lis tada como um exem plo de Critério B2 (fla shbac k) e B5 ("re atividade física”). Além disso, são necessários mais estudos explora ndo os asp ectos neurobiol ógicos sobre a IT pós-traumática em paci entes c om TEPT e no grupo controle. É possível que esses pacientes com TEPT e IT pós -traumática consti tuam um s ubtipo de TEPT, assim como foi verificad a a existê ncia de um subtipo dissociativo (LANIUS et al., 2010).

1.2.3 Imobilidade tônica e dissociaç ão peritraumát icas – relação com a qualidade d e vida em pacientes com TEPT A imobi lidade tônica e dissociação são fenôm enos correlacionados que podem diferir de modo dimensi onal, ao in vés de catego rial. A dissoc iação peritrau mática caracteriza -se por alte rações na perc epção do tempo, lugar e da pesso a e uma sensação de irrealidade no mo mento do acontecime nto (CARDEÑA ; SPIE GEL, 1993; MARM AR; WEISS ; METZLER, 1998). O entorpecimen to emoc ional relacionad o à dissociação pod e ser med iado por mecanismos biológico s semelha ntes àquele s que estão subjacentes à IT (ABRAMS et al., 2009). Inclusive há sintomas relacionados à diss ociação peritraumá tica que se sobrepõem àqueles apresentados na IT, tant o que há sintomas dissociativos nas esc alas de IT, como a perda de memóri a, do rmência e des cone xão de si mesmo ( FUSÉ et al., 2007; HEIDT et al., 2005 ; MARX et al.,2008). É possível que a IT seja uma express ão extre ma de dissociação peritraumátic a (ABRAMS e t al., 20 09). Porém, ainda não estão claros qu ais os marc adore s subjetivos distintos e comp artilhados de c ada construc to (ZOELLNE R, 2008 ).

A dissociaçã o e imobilidade tônica estão asso ciada s a um mai or ris co para o desenvolv imento e g ravidade d os sintomas de TEPT, assim como pior resp osta ao tratamen to (BREH ; SEIDLE R, 2007; FISZMAN et al., 2008 ; OZER et al., 2003; ROCHA -REGO et al. , 2009 ; VAN DER VELDEN ; WITTMANN , 2008 ). De fat o, são

fortes p reditor es de TEPT crônico : a percepção de ameaç a à vida, a gravid ade do evento tr aumátic o e as rea ções peritraumá ticas (OZER et al., 2003) . É sabido que o TEPT crôni co está associado a comorbidades psiquiátricas graves ( por exemplo , depressão, suicíd io e abuso / dependência de substâncias ) (BRADY et al., 2000) e clínica s (por exemplo , dores musculoesqu eléticas e doenças cardiovasculares e autoimunes ) (PACELLA ; HR USKA; DELAH ANTY, 2013; YEHUDA et al., 2015). A carga global de doenças - sofrimento, incap acidade e mortalidade prematura - relacionadas a o TEPT é muito al ta (YE HUD A et al., 2015) . Também está a ssociado a prejuízos laborati vos, sociais e familiares e a redução dos ní veis de qualidade de vida (QV) (BALAYAN et al., 2014; MCFARLANE, 2017; NACHAR e t al., 2013).
Porém, ainda é pouco explorado o papel das reações peritr aumáticas na quali dade de vida do s pacientes com TEPT.

A qualidade de vid a (QV) é uma impo rtante medida d e des fecho clí nico, ainda relativamente negligenciada (MEND LOWICZ ; STEIN, 2000) . É um construto multidime nsional que pode s er definido como “ a percepç ão do indiví duo de sua posição na vida, no contexto da cultu ra e sistema d e valores nos qua is ele vive e e m relação aos seus objetivos, expectativas, padrões e preoc upações . É um c oncei to amplo, afetado de manei ra compl exa pela s aúde física e esta do psicol ógico do indivíduo, seu nível de independência, relaçõe s soc iais do indiví duo e sua relação com caracterís ticas importan tes d e seu a mbiente ” (WORLD HEALTH ORGANIZATI ON, 199 6). Comp reend e os domínios psicológico, físico, social e ambi ental e a aval iação des ses domínios pode revel ar o impac to total de uma condiç ão cl ínica na vida de um paciente (M END LOWICZ ; STEI N, 20 00).

Há uma e scassez na literatura de abordagens holí sticas que aval iam a relação entre qualidade d e vida e reações p eritraumáticas. Id entificam os apenas dois estudos que explor aram essa associação e demo nstraram que a dissociação peritraumática pred iz um a pobre Q V em imigran tes expostos a eventos traumático s (HIAR et al., 2016 ; KOUNOU et al., 2017). Sendo assim, decidim os investiga r a associação entre imobil idade tônic a e dissoc iação peritraumática s e qualidad e de vida em pacientes com TEPT numa amos tra ambulatorial brasileira .

Abstract

This narrative review integra tes the results of almost 30 years of research related to PTSD and tonic immobility (TI) in rape trauma victims - rape-induced tonic immobility. Considered the last-ditch of the defens ive cascade, TI is an innate and involuntary reaction elicit in the context of intense fear and perceived inescapability . It may occur not only during or in the aftermath of the traumatic event (peritraumatic TI) but as a PTSD re-experiencing symptom (post -traumatic TI), contributing to additional distress . Although considered adaptative in animals , rape induced-TI is associat ed with PTSD severity and poor prognosis and negative post-traumatic cognitions related to the inability to avoid the attack . Additio nally, TI might prevent serious injuries but not rape completion . Despit e being yet overlo oked, TI has potential devastating clinical consequences and critical legal implication s.

3.1 Peritr aumatic tonic immobility in rape victims

Peritraumatic reactions are victims ' cognitive, beh avioral and em otional reactions during or immediately after expos ure to a threatening situation ( Bovin & Marx , 2011; Kozlowska et al., 2015; Mar x et al., 2008; Oze r et al., 2003 ). These reactions may be automatically activated in the context of danger and negatively experienced as overwhelming , contributing to distress and PTS D symptoms (Abrams et al. , 2012; Brewin et al. , 2000; Bryant, 2003; Kaysen et al., 2005 ; Kunst et a l., 2011; Ozer et al., 2003). In fact, t he peritraumatic rape induced -tonic immob ility may contribute to deleterious mental health outcomes , mainly PTSD ( Bovin et al., 2008; Coxell & King, 2010 ; Hagenaars, 2016; Heidt et al., 2005; Humphreys et al. , 2010; Kalaf et al., 201 5; 2017; Marx e t al., 2008; Möller et al., 2017; Rocha -Rego et a l., 2009) . TI has been associated with significant PTSD symptoms severity (Bovi n et al., 2008; Fiszman et al., 2008; Humphreys et al., 2010; Lexington, 2007 ; Rocha -Rego et al., 2009; Lima et a l., 2010; Portu gal et al., 2012; Maia et al., 2015; De Kleine et al., 2018), poor treat ment response and prognosis (Fiszman et al., 2008; Lima et al., 2010) and impai red recovery ( Hagenaars , Hagenaars, 2020) .

The association betwe en peri traum atic TI and P TSD development and severity may be related to overwhelming distress, hel plessness, and inescapability perception during the attack ( Abrams et al., 2012; Bovin et al. , 2008; Chiver s-Wilson , 2006 ; Hagenaars & Putman, 2011; Kuiling e t al., 2019; Marx et al., 2008 ; Schauer & Elbert, 2010 ; Van Buren & Weierich, 2 015). The uncontrol lable shaking and the inability to move or scream for help - all the i nvoluntary TI elements – may contribu te to the fear of recurrence of the immobility resp onse in future attacks , aggravat ing their sense of uncontrollability and unpred ictability of their reactions (Bovin et al., 2008; Morrison, 2020 ; TeBockhorst , 2012; Tebockhorst et al., 201 5). Other propose d mechanism s

are greater sensory intake and consequ ent sen sory-rich trauma m emories (Hagena ars & Putman, 2011; Hagenaars et al. , 2008), and increased guilt, self - blame, and blame by others (Bovin et al., 2014).

The ada ptative role of peritra umatic tonic i mmobility as an immediate self- protective reaction is stil l uncertain. Durin g a rape, being verbally and physically immobile may e ffectively protect from brutality and additional physical harm (see Gidycz & Dardis, 20 14). However, active and assertive resistance strategies may be more effective in preventing rape completi on or escalation, despite only nearly 25% of women survivo rs of sexual assau lt engage in th ese active defenses (Ullman, 2007). Regarding the relatio nship between active resistance and increased injury risk, findings ar e less clear . Many situational and co ntextual factors may be involved, as the perpetrato r's use of physical force or weapon, pri or ingestion of alcohol , stranger or ac quaintance rapist (see Ullman, 20 07). Moreover , rape is a hidden and underreported crime (Tidmarsh & Hamilton, 2 020). 3.3 Negative post -trauma cogn itions – the role of guil t and sham e Guilt, shame , and self -blame are mala daptive post -traumatic beliefs relate d to PTSD development and se verity ( Bovin et al., 2014; Carretta & Szymanski, 2 020; Ehlers & Clark, 2000 ; Galliano et al., 1993 ; López -Castro et al., 2 019; Saraiya & Lopez-Castro, 2016 ). This rel ationship is consistent for rape induced -tonic immobility . First, rape is a demeaning an d dehumanizing trauma by its very nature since the victim is subjugated and vio lated (Moor et al., 2013 ). Secondly, being p aralyzed during rape leads to additional feelings of hel plessness , and inescapability , which are features related to negative post -traumatic cognitions, distress, and PTSD symptoms (Mgolozeli & Duma, 2020 ; Morris on, 2020; TeBockhorst et al., 201 5; Van Bure n & Weierich, 2015 ). 4. Legal implications

The occurrence of peritraumatic tonic imm obility adds another layer of complex ity to th e already challeng ing task of adj udicating cases of ra pe and sexu al assault . Only those fam iliarized with this phenomenon will be c apable of addressing this challenge effectively. The peritraumatic TI phenomeno n poses a potentially serious challen ge to the misconceptions be hind the "resis tance sta ndard " and t he rape scripts (Schiewe , 2019) . During an episode of sexual assault, a person who falls in a state of TI may become unable not on ly to deny consent but also to offer resis tance. A sexual attack without the ex pected verb al or physical resistance is likely to be misconstru cted by the legal sys tem as a conse nsual sexual relationship (Freyd, 2008) . However, a s Schiewe (2019) suggested , TI should be recognized as a state of "incapacity -to-resist -or-consent " by its very nature , potentially representing a biologic al marker of non-consent.

Older cri minal statutes commonly included a "resistance standa rd." To characterize a rape case, the vi ctim had not only to deny consent – the "non-consent standard " – but als o to offer an acti ve resistance a gainst the sexual aggr ession that could only be overcome b y the use of c onsiderable physical force by the would -be aggressor (Dworkin ,1966 ; Tidmarsh & Hamilton, 2020 ). The legal requirement that the victim should strongly r esist the aggresso r's sexual adva nces to prove that she/he was rape d has now disa ppeared fr om the statute books (Levine, 2018).

Despite this, th e cultural and institutional mindset beh ind the resistance standard endures, po lice officers, prosecutors, juror s, and part of the society, in ge neral, continue to loo k to the lev el of the vict im's resis tance in ascer taining the two core elements of rape – non-consent , and force ( Carr et al., 20 14; Rerick et al., 2019 ; Schiewe, 2019 ; Tidmarsh & Hamilton, 2020 ). Thes e attitudes subscr ibe to rape myths (Burt, 1980 ) and th e unrealisti c expectation that a vic tim can and sh ould respond with either fight or fligh t, ignoring the defensive cascade framew ork and TI reaction ( Bracha et al., 200 4; Karl Umbrasas, 2020; Schiewe, 2019).

Rape survi vors are unique ly vulnerable to being blamed for their own atta ck compare d to other int erpersonal crimes. Crucial among the ma ny unusual features of rape cases is the extent to which the victim and her/his personal characteristics and

present and past beha vior are also "on trial ," much like t hose of the perpetrator him/herself (Rerick et al. , 2019). Prevailing cognitive biases, s uch as the Belief in a Just World ( Lerne r, 1977) and the Rape Myth Acceptance ( Burt, 1980; Payne et al., 1999 ) fuels the phenomeno n of victim -blaming to a degree rarel y found in o ther crimes (Rerick et al., 2019), while simultaneously absolving the perpetr ator, and minimizing or justifying the a ggression (Briggs & Scott, 2020 ; Payne et al., 1999). Studies demonstra ted that aggressor culpability was higher, and the victi ms receive more significan t social s upport and acc eptance when the victim strongly resist ed physically, fighting during the entir e encounter. On the other hand, rape su rvivors that complied with assai lants related to de vastating terro r were generally treat ed with skep ticism and cyn icism by p olice and othe r professionals (Gravelin et al., 2019 ; Tidmarsh & Hamilton, 2020 ).

Known as se condary victimization, the adverse expe riences with post-assault legal a nd medical assista nce and negativ ely perceived support may intensif y and perpetua te distres s in sexual as sault survivors (Campbell et al. , 2001 ). Rape induced -tonic immobility is still an under -recognized reaction . The very nature of TI itself predisposes survivors to fall into categories likely to be seen as suspicious b y investigator s (Graveli n et al., 2019 ). These victims frequently experience a lack of empathy and mistrust , being hi storically mistreated by the criminal j ustice system (Burt 1980; Campbel l & Wasco, 2005 ; Persson & Dhingr a, 2020 ). Blaming the victim may not only impair recovery but diminishes the likelihood of justice (Campbell et al., 2001 ; Persson & Dhingra, 2020 ).
5. Limitations

Limitations are related to the narrative review method s. The scientific quali ty of included studies was no t considered . There is a risk of selection b ias, as an over- representation of adult s and women/girls raped by men/boys in most studies. In this review , particular populations were not precisely explored, inclu ding sexual and gender orientatio ns, racial/ethnic differences, prior sexual tra uma history , victim- offen der relationshi p, and pre-assault use of alcohol . Additionally, the authors' subjectivity may influence study selection and interpretation of the infor mation .
6. Implications for research and practice

Unfortunately, the rape induced-tonic i mmo bility has been historically neglected by researchers, clinicians, and forensic profe ssion als. A standardized TI assessmen t should be incorporated into scientific investigat ions and clinical and forensic practice s, recognizing that it is a co mmon rape r esponse a ssociated with negative outcomes (Marx et al., 2008). We claim widespread psych oeduc ation regarding its neurobiologi cal and clinical aspects and mandatory t raining for medica l services and law enforcement office rs. It may debunk rape my ths and vic tim-blami ng attitudes and promote a more supportive environment in medical services and the justice system , facilitating disclosure , appropriate assistance , support , and recove ry (Cam pbell et al., 2 020; Chivers -Wilson , 2006).

Additionally, rape awareness training and s elf-defense and sexual assault resistance programs have become popular, pa rticularly at colleges and universiti es (Gidycz, Dardis, 2014 ; McCaughey, Cermele, 2017) . We ad vise including information about the defens ive cascade and the passive re sponses as a possible self-protective strateg y, other than fight or flight . For the rap e surv ivors, knowing that this immobi lity response is typical and automatic ma y reduce d istress and negative po st-traumatic cognitions (Bovin et al., 2014; Va n Buren & Weierich, 2015; Zoellner, 2008). Validating and normalizing how people respond to trauma may help them recuperate a sense of normality and health in their lives, cont ributing t o the manage ment of the negative cogn itions and recovery ( Ullman et al., 2014 ).

Future resear ch should explore the impact of different self-protective behaviors durin g a se xual assault to avoid additiona l harm or rape completion . They should in clude the influenc e of suspect -victim relationships (e.g. , intimate, strangers) on rape res istance strate gies and outcomes and how types of perpetrators may influence the resista nce st rategies .
7. Conclusions

This review synthesized almost 30 years of res earch on rape indu ced-tonic immob ility and PTSD . Our findings are relevant to expand the kn owledge about this innate and involuntary defensive cascade reaction during rape and its clin ical and legal implications . Mounting evidence suggests that rape induce d-tonic immobility

may not be con sidered adaptative in humans. Although being i mmobile duri ng the attack may reduce the risk of severe injury, it may not avoid rape completion or escal ation (Ullman, 2007 ). Besides , TI is related to negative outcomes. Abstract Despite tonic immobility (TI) being the last -ditch defense strategy elicited by an extreme threat, it is still neglected in PTSD research and clinical practice. I t may be one of the most characteristic and prevalent phenomena related to PTSD. Traditionally described as a peritraumatic reaction, posttra umat ic TI may also be elicited during re -experiencing the traumatic event. The uncontrollable recurrence of the imm obility phenomenon in dai ly life may be an overwhelming experience in itself, sustaining feelings of fear and helplessness. Living under the “shadow of TI” - a long - standi ng impact of recurrent TI – may contribute t o ad ditional distress and PTSD severity a nd chronicity. We suggest that future revisions of the DSM should list TI as an example of Criterion B2 as a flashback and B5 as “physical re activity after exposure to tra umatic remind ers”. During the immobility state, she had a flashbac k, smelling beer and barbecue. “It was like everything was occurri ng agai n.” Indeed, the smell of beer and barbe cue triggered her child abuse memories when she was in her early 40s . After that, she manifested late onset of PTSD symptoms. Her father had rep eatedly abused her physically and sexually from the age of 8 until she wa s 14 years old.

Abou t the immobil ity state, she said that it is not rare , and it had already occurred several times, even during a nightmare, when she woke up feeling immobile and being impossible to call for help. ” (Personal commu nication of the assistant physician).

The description above illustrated one of the most extreme reactions to life - threatening - tonic immobility (TI) - that was completely ignored in the diagnostic criteria for post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) b y the official classifications (DSM -
5 and ICD-10).1,2 Although neglected, TI might be one of the most typical and

prevalent phenomena related to PTSD . 3-6 Traditionally described as a peritraumatic reaction , TI also occurs during re -experiencing the trauma tic event.7 Post-traumatic tonic immobilit y wa s demonstrated in experimental and clinical research , but its occurrence remains largely unrecognized in academic and clinical settings. Indeed, the blindness towards the human TI phenomenon is pervasive. As pa rt of the defensive cascade, T I has been de scribed in the phylogenetic scale for more than three centuries .8 On the other hand, in humans, the active fight and flight defensive reactions have received the majority attention of the scientific interest .

Tonic immobility has been descri bed in many s pecies as the last -ditch anti - predator reaction along the defensive cascade. It occurs in response to an overwhelming and inescapable threat an d is characterized by profo und p hysical immobility, lack of vocalizati on, and analgesia .8,9 In human s, researcher s, have confused this stage of the defensive cascade with freezing or attentive immobility .10,11 This misunderstanding delayed the incorporation of this defensive reactio n in psychiatry - mainly in PTSD . Although in the last 15 years , the publ ications about peritraumatic TI in humans have drastically increased , it is still modest in absolute number (figure 1). Peritraumatic TI - during or in the af termath of a traumatic ev ent - has been recognized as an important c linical predictor of PTSD deve lopment, severi ty, and poor outcomes .4-6,12-22 Besides, peritraumatic TI has been related to the re-experiencing symptom cluster of PTSD .12,16,23

Despite the growing body of researc h abou t peritraumatic TI, post-traumatic TI remains under -investigated. We demonstrated that trauma reminders may evoke post-traumatic TI in experimental situations .11,24 Biological indicators of TI in humans

in the laboratory setting included reduced bod y sway , tachycardia, low heart rate variabi lity11,24, and heightened card iac defense res pons e to an abrupt sound.25 Accordingly, de Kleine and colleagues7 found that more than 70% of chronic PTSD patients reported mo derate to extreme TI during re -experienc ing th e traumatic event. Besides, post -traumatic TI mediated the relation ship between pe ritraumatic TI and PTSD symptoms severity.7 Recognizing the importance of this clinical phenomenon, Lloyd and colleagues26 devel oped a specific questionnaire to assess post-trauma tonic immobility - the Scale fo r Tonic immobility Occurring P ost-trauma (STO P).26

Undergoing TI as part of the re -experiencing PTSD symptoms cluster may be an overwhelming experience in itself. This expe rience potentially reinforces the fear and help lessness associated with repeated in voluntary immobility. As descr ibed in a quali tative study by TeBockhorst: 27 “…repeated intrusion into their lives is distressing and frightening and leaves them fearing th at the immobility could return at any tim e. It makes it more difficult for these sur vivors to heal because the pas t continues to reappear as a current stressor”.27 The “shadow of TI” was coined by TeBockhorst27 to describe lingering residual psych osocial effects of the repeated experiences of TI.27,28 Over the long term, recurrent TI reactions may contribut e to additional distress, social misfunctioning, interpersonal avoidance , and compromis ed wellbeing .26

Recurrent posttraumatic TI may lead to chronic stress overload, rendering the patients m ore vuln erable to the hazardous consequence s of repetitive activation of stress medi ators on the regulation of brain and body allostasis .7,26,29,30 Besides, recurrent a ctivation of posttraumatic ‘‘fear network’’ may compromise fear reduction (i.e., extinct ion) and extinction retention30-32, contri buting to the chronicity and severity of PTSD.

Considering that daily life trauma reminders - external (e.g., via media news) or internal (e.g. , unwanted thoughts or flashbacks) - can trigger tonic immobility -like reaction s, we suggest that future revision s of t he DSM should list TI as an exa mple of Criterion B2 as a flashback and B5 as “physical reactivity after exposure to traumatic reminders .” Accordingly, instruments designed to assess PTSD, such as the CAPS, should als o enquire about TI as a specific b ehavio ral manifestation of PTS D.
Additionally, active screening about recurring TI should be mandatory in the assessment of every trauma -exposed victim.

Summary Background : Posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD ) is a prevalent and disabling multisystem disord er, with significant physical and psychi atric morbidity and poor quality of life (QOL). Although peritraumatic reactions - tonic immobility and dissocia tion - are established predictors of PTSD severity and developme nt, there is a dearth of investiga tion assessing the impact of peritraumat ic reactions on QOL of PTSD patient s. Qual ity of life has become increasingly important in health care and research as a reliable outcome measure . It comprises psychological , physica l, social , and environmental domai ns, providing important information abou t the impact of

diseases on a patie nt's life. This study aims to investigate the impact of peritraumatic tonic immobility and peritraumatic dissociation on QOL of PTSD civilian outpa tients. Subjects and methods : It is a cross-sectio nal study of 50 victims of urban violence with current PTSD, recruited in a specialized outpatient clinic . Instruments used were: Structured Clinical Interview IV, Peritraumatic Dissociative Exper iences Questionnaire, Tonic Immobility Scale, and WHOQOL -BREF (psychological, physi cal, social, and environm ental doma ins). Linear regression models were fitted to evaluate the impact of peritraumatic react ions - tonic immobility and dissociation - on WHOQ OL-BREF scores. We controlled for sex as potentia l confoundi ng.

Results : The sever ity of peritraumatic tonic immobili ty nega tively impacted on psychological and environment domains of quality of life. For each additional point on the Tonic Immobility Scale, there was a decrease of 0.8 points on the scores of these domains of WHOQOL -BREF . Neither the peritraumat ic reactio ns show ed effects on physical nor social domains. Possible limitations of this study include cross -sectional design, a relatively small sample size of tertiary center outpatients , and recall bias. Conclusions : Peritraumat ic tonic immobility is related to poor quality of life, adding new insights about the relationship between this immobility reaction and PTSD. Keywords : peritraumatic reactio ns; disso ciation ; tonic immobility; quality of life; post- traumatic stress disorder .

Introduction Posttraum atic stres s disor der (PTSD) is a prevalent, comp lex, and debilitating multisystem disorder (McFarlane 2017 ; Yehuda et al. 2015 ) that is linked with several severe psychiatric (e.g., depressio n, anxiety, subst ance abuse/dependence , and suicidality) (Brady et al. 2000 ) and medical comorbidities (e.g., cardiovascular and autoimmune diseases , musculoskeletal pain and gastrointestinal symptoms ) (Pacella et al. 2013 ; Yehuda et al. 2015 ). PTSD is also associated with vocational, social , and familial dysfunctions , and low levels of quality of life (QOL ) (Balayan et al. 2014; McFarlane 2017 ; Nachar et al. 2013 ). Indeed, the overall disease burden - suffering,

disabilit y, and premature mortality - related to PTSD is thus very high (Yehuda et al. One of the strongest predicto rs of PTSD development is the peritraumatic reactions (Aho et al. 2017 ; Breh & Seidler 2007 ; Brewin et al. 2000 ; Ozer et al. 2003 ; Rocha -Rego et al. 2009 ). These are complex psychop hysiologica l reactions experienced during or in the immedi ate afterm ath of a traumatic event (Bovin & Marx 2011), including peritraumatic dissociation (PD) and tonic immobility (PTI) . Peritraumatic dissocia tion is characterized by a sense of unreali ty and alteration s in the perception of time, place, and person (Cardeña & Spiegel 1993 ; Marmar et al. 1998a ). It is a well-establish ed construct in the PTSD literatur e (Breh & Seidler 2007 ; Lensvelt -Mulders et al. 2008 ; Ozer et al. 2003 ; Velden & Witmann 2008 ) with considerable progress concerning its neurobiological correlates (Breh & Seidler 2007 ; Koenen et al. 2005 ). It has been shown to be a very important risk factor for PTSD (Breh & Seidler 2007 ; Ozer et al. 2003) .

Peritraum atic tonic immobi lity is characterized by involuntary motor and vocal inhibition, analgesia , and tremors with preserved awareness of the surroundings . This reaction is elicited in perceived inescapa ble, life-threatening situations (Bracha 2004; Fusé et al. 2007; Galliano et al. 1993; Heidt et al. 2005 ; Marx et al. 2008 ). Although described in nonhuman animals for centuries (Maser & Gallup 1977), tonic immobilit y has received limited attention in huma ns. Recentl y, its biological relev ance was confirmed by experimental studie s (Mooren & Minnen 2014; Volchan et al. 2011) . PTI is a predictor of PTSD development (Bovin et al. 2008 ; Heidt et al. 2005; Humphre ys et al. 2010 ; Kalaf et al. 2015; Maia et al. 2015; Portuga l et al. 2012; Rocha -Rego et al. 2009 ), symptom severity (Bovin et al. 2008; Humphreys et al. 2010; De Kleine et al. 2018; Maia et al. 2015; Portugal et al. 2012; Rocha -Rego et al. 2009) and poor therapeut ic outcome (Fiszman et al. 2008; Lima et al. 2010). An important though relatively neglected clinical outco me meas ure is quality of life (QOL ) (Mendlowicz & Stein 2000 ). It is a multidimensional construct that can be defined as “an individual's perception of their position in life in the contex t of the culture and value system in which they live and in relation to their goals, expectations and standards and concerns. It is a broad ranging concept affected in a complex way

by the person's physical health, psychological state, level of indep endenc e, social relationships, and their relationship to salient features of their environment ” (World Health Organization 1996 ). The construct of QOL comprises several domains, including the psychological, physic al, socia l and environmental ones. Assessme nt of these domai ns may unveil the full impa ct of a disease on a patient's life (Mendlowicz In fact, there is a dearth of holistic approaches that assess the quality of life in PTSD patients reporti ng peritr aumatic reactions. Only two studie s explored the relationship between peritraumatic reactions and QOL and showed that PD predicts a poor QOL in traumatized immigrants (Hiar et al. 2016; Kounou et al. 2017) . On the other hand , no studies are invest igating the association between peritraumat ic tonic immobility and quality of life in PTSD patients.

The aim of the present study is to investigate the impact of peritraumatic dissociation and peritraumatic tonic immobility on the quality of life of PTSD civilian outpatients. We hypothesize that both peritra umatic dissociation and tonic immobility would predict impairmen t in most areas of quality of life in PTSD patients. Subjects and methods Participants It is a cross-sectional study of 50 victims of urban violence with current PTSD secondary to armed robbery (35%), kidnapping (24.5%), traffic accident s (12%), shooting (4%), sexual assault or rape (4%), and others (20.5%). The mean (SD) age was 40 years (SD = 8.2), 54% were men, 74% were married or living with a partner , and 62% had at least some college education (table 1).

All partic ipants signed informed cons ent and were recruited from an outpatient university clinic specialized in posttraumatic stress. The study was approved by the Ethics Committee of the Institute of Psychiatry of Federal University of Rio de Janeiro, Brazil .

WHO's Quality of Life Instrument - Short Version (WHOQOL -BREF) To assess QOL , we used the self-reporti ng Brazilian -Portuguese version of the WHOQ OL-BREF, which compr ises 26 items with four broad domains of QOL : psychological, physical health, social relationships, and environmental. All scores are scaled in a positive direct ion and range from 0 to 100 (Skevington 2002 ). Peritraumatic Dissocia tive Experie nces Questionn aire (PDEQ) Peritraumatic dissociation (PD) was assessed through the Peritraumatic Dissociative Experiences Questionnaire (PDEQ) (Fiszman et al. 2005; Marmar et al. 1998b ). This scale is comp osed of 10 items, each presenting a 5-point Likert-type selecti on - rangin g from 1 (not at all) to 5 (extremely ) for the intensity of dissociative phenomenon during or immediately after trauma exposure.

Tonic Immobility Scale (TIS) To assess peritraumati c tonic immob ility (PTI), we emplo yed a validated Brazilian version of the Tonic Immobility Scale (TIS) (Reichenheim et al. 2014). The original version of this self-report Likert scale has ten items, each one with a seven - point scale, and physical immobili ty and fear as two independent factors (Fusé et al. 2007). The Brazilian version of TIS has only one-factor, reduced number of items (from ten to six), and scores range from 0 to 36. The TIS scores were based on the worst experienced trauma (Reichenheim et al. 2014).

Statistical analysis Firstly, we assessed the patients` charac teristics according to sociodemographic variables and types of worst trauma. We also calculated the score means and respective standard deviations for the two types of peritraumatic reactions and the four domains of WHOQOL -BREF.

Secondly, linear regressio n models were fitted to evaluate the impact of PTI and PD on the scores of WHOQOL -BREF . This analysis was carried out separately for each domain of QOL . As the exploratory analysis showed that sex was associated with peritra umati c reaction s and QOL, we included it in all models to
control potential confounding. P-values ≤ 0.05 were considered statistically significant .
All analys es were carried out in Stata 14.

For each additional point on the TIS, there was a decrease of 0.8 points on the scores of the psychological and environment al domains of WHOQOL -BREF. Discussion This is the first study investigating the impact of peritraumatic tonic immobility (PTI) on quality of life (QOL ). We found that PTI seve rity predicted poor QOL on the psycho logical and envir onmental domains in PTSD civilian outpatients . Quality of life has become increasingly important in health care and research as a reliable outcome measure based on economic, health-related, and environm ental parameters (Mendlowicz & Stein 2000; Pupo et al. 2015 ). It comprises “inside factors ” like the symptoms severity , type of disorder, como rbidities , and “outside factors ” such as culture, socia l support, socioeconomic status , and medical care quality and accessibility (Sosnowski et al. 2017). Addressing QOL contributes to an accurate evaluation of mental illness that goes beyond the patient’ s symptom profile and includes an individual perception of their own position in life (Mendlowicz The mechanism s involved in the association between poor QOL and PTSD remain incompletely understood . Mounting research highlights PTSD is an often chronic and disabling condit ion, with significant physi cal and psychiatric morbidity and high personal, social , and economic costs (Araú jo et al. 2014; Pagotto et al. 2015; Sareen et al. 2007; Spitzer et al. 2009 ). Factors related to the individual (e.g., age, sex, coping strategies) , PTSD (e.g., severity, como rbidities ), the traumatic event (e.g., type, recurrence , and magnitude) , and peritraumatic reactions may impact QOL (Bomyea et al. 2012 ).

Conceivably, the impact of peritraumatic tonic immobility on the QOL of PTSD patients could be mediated by direct and indirect mechanisms. PTI could impair QOL through a direct impact on mental health. For example, feelings of immobility and loss of control in response to situations of perceived life threat and overwhelming fear may lead to intense peritraumatic distress with potentially devastating effect s on mental health (Ozer et al. 2003; TeBockhorst et al. 2015. ). Indirectly, PTI may be related to poor QOL through PTSD itself, since this peritraum atic reacti on was found to be a clinical marker for PTSD severity and worse treatment response and prognosis (Fiszman et al. 2008; Kalaf et al. 2015; Lima et al. 2010; Maia et al. 2015; Portugal et al. 2012; Rocha -Rego et al. 2009).

According to the prese nt study, PTI severity negatively impacts the psychological domain of QOL - which evaluates how much a person experiences positive and nega tive feelings, thinking , and self-esteem, including feelings of peace, happiness , and hopefulness (WHOQOL Group 1994 ). Hypotheti cally, PTI could negatively impa ct psychologica l QOL in several ways. First, a possible mechanism is the sensation of helplessn ess and horror trigge red by the involuntary and uncontro llable immobility reaction . Appraisals of low control may lead to negativ e emotions (e.g., pessimism, passivity), nega tive cognitions (about the self, about the world) , and maladaptive coping strate gies, contributing to posttraumatic psychological distress , psychopathology , and poor mental well-being (Ehlers & Clark 2000 ; Skinn er 1996 ). Indeed, Van Buren and Weierich (2015) found that peritraumatic perceived inescapability was positively associated with negative cognitions about the self and the world, avoidance/numbing symptoms, and PTSD severity in survivors of childhood sexual abuse. Furthe r, as hypothesized by TeBockh orst et al. (2015), a “residual impact” of PTI may persist, keeping the horror and helplessness associated with this reaction.

Second, re-experiencing the immobility reaction triggered by trauma reminders (e.g., intrusive thoug hts or flashbacks) and subsequ ent stressors (Hagenaars et al. 2008 ) may exacerbate the effects of PTI itself. De Kleine et al. (2018) demonstrated that re-experiencing tonic immobility fully mediated the association between PTI and PTSD symptoms severity. Re-experiencing PTI triggered by trauma reminde rs could even worsen feelings of loss of control and negative reappraisal - essential features of PTSD perpet uation (Ehlers & Clark 2000) . Since trauma reminders can evoke PTI, the next revision of DSM could consider tonic immob ility reactio n in the B5 criteria since this is a “physical reactivity after exposure to traumatic reminders” (American Psychiatric Association 2013).

Finally, a third possible mechanism is that victims often feel guilty and ashamed by not having been able to react or scream, misinterpreting the PTI reaction as a personal weakness - main ly in victims of sexual trauma (Marx et al. 2008; TeBockhorst et al. 2015). Also, concerns about others` opinions about being sexually assault ed have a strong influence on coping and PTSD symptoms (Guay et al. 2006 ; Ullman 1999). If rape victims did not attempt to scape and show active

struggling, they are more likely to be blamed, resulting in less emotional support and contributing to more maladaptive negative cognition s about themselv es (decreased self-worth, hopelessness), negative cognitions about the world (judged as a dangerous and hostile place), and psychological distress (Ehlers & Clark 2000; Ozer et al. 2003 ). Hence, the presence and severity of posttraumatic negative cognition s have been assumed to be a risk factor for PTSD sympto ms (Bomyea et al. 2012; Van Buren & Weierich 2015) and, maybe, poor QOL.

Our second main finding was that PTI predicted low environmental QOL scores . This domain includ es the person’s sense of indepen dence, physical safety , and security , the discernment of how his/her income is "enough" to obtain the needs and desires for a healthy and comfortable lifestyle. It encompasses the ability to pursue one’s interests , housing, health , social care facilities and quality, recreation , leisure activities , and physical environmen t (WHOQOL Group 1994 ). Although the authors of the QOL construct do not state this directly, we suggest that the environmental domain enquiry seem s to be related to the concept of personal well- being and life satisfaction since the environmental domain englobes factors that lead people to experience their lives as worthwhile and rewarding subjectively (Diener et al. 2018 ). It could be hypothesized that the environmental domain concept might be considered an umbrella term for the overall synthesis of QOL , in which an individual`s gene ral needs - like the level of independence and overall subjective well-being and overall life satisfaction - are met. Thus, the environment domain provides an “origina l contribution” to assessing overall QOL in health (Skevington & McCrate 2012 ).

The factors and circumstance s that may affect the quality of life in the environmental domain are still understudied . It has been shown that lack of support from family - and possibly from peers, organizati ons, the legal system , and the broader external experience environment - are associated with worse WHOQOL - BREF environmental domain scores (Wig et al. 2006) . Family support may be an important resource of the immediate environment of the victim of traumatic events , providing not only material support but also a sense of safet y, security , and normality. Most rape and sexual violence victims tell friends and relatives about their assault and receive both positive and negative social reactions upon disclosure. The former,

which includes listening to the victim and maki ng him/her feel believed, is associated with fewer emotional and physical health problems (Campbell et al. 2001 ). In contrast , the latter, which encompasses what is known as the rape myth - prejudicial, stereotyped, or false beliefs about rape, rape victim s, and rapists, such as "any healthy woman can resist a rapist if she really wants to" – creates a climate that is hostile to rape victims (Burt 1980) , fosters self-blame and stigma and exacerbates physical and psychological distress (Ullma n 1999) .

Police investigatio ns of rape and other serious sexual offen ses usually occur in an organizational context shaped by masculine ethos, misogynist values , and preconceived beliefs regarding this kind of crime. An attitude of suspiciousness regardi ng women’s testimony tends to be pervasive in police processing of rape complaints. Serious bodily injuries are accepted by the police as evidence that rape has indeed occurred and are often considered as a sine qua non-corroborative feature . Many victims may fall into a state of immobility during the rape, further undermining the complainer's credibility and thus reinforcing advers e social reactions Historically, many courts adopted the “reasonable resistance requirement ,” which required the victim to attempt to resist the attacker phys ically. The underlying assumption was that physical resistance amounted to evidence of no consent. Only recently, courts acknowledged that physiological mechanisms could render rape victims immobile without implying conse nt (MacKinnon 2016). Also, members of some occupational groups such as firefighters , soldiers , and police officers can undergo adminis trative restrictions if they paralyze in response to traumatic on-the- job events (Ly et al. 2017; Maia et al. 2015 ; Marmar et al. 1994 ). Clearly, disseminati on of research on tonic immobility for the military and civilian justice system and society is esse ntial for justice to be done for trauma victim s. Tonic immobility may be associated with compromi sed environmenta l quality of life in other contexts. Maia et al. (2015) remarked that “… Police work involves frequen t exposure to high-risk situations that often require an active response. For police officers facin g imminently dangerous situations, such as shootings or high- speed pursuits, to experience tonic immobility could be physically and psychologically damaging … Furthermore, given the low level of public awareness

regarding the existence of tonic immobility in humans, the lack of purposeful action in these contexts could be misinterpreted (and even stigmatized) as cowardice or another major moral flaw by the police officer or by third parties …” (p. 52). Indeed, up to 14.3% of the police officers may experienc e a “freezing” reaction while facing particularly stressfu l events (Karl sson & Christia nson 2003) . Reprimand, gossip, humiliation , or even harassment or ostracism by fellow police officers may make the work environment unbearabl e (Hunt 1985) . Similar sequences of events leading to comparable outcomes may occur with other high-risk occupations, such as military exposure to combat situa tions (Van der Hart et al. 2001 ) and rescuers facing life‐threatening or fatal disasters (Leach 2004) .

Our study could not find evidence of the impact of PTI neither on physical and social domains nor of peritraumat ic dissociation (PD) on any domain of QOL . Only two previous studies reported an association between PD and impaired QOL (Hiar et al. 2016; Kouno u et al. 2017). The divergence between our and those studies ' findings could be explained by distinct sample characteristics and methodological issues . While our sample was a clinical one, theirs was composed of refugees affected by the Arab Spring (Hiar et al. 2016) and by the Ivory Coast socio political crisis (Kounou et al. 2017). Our study has a cross -sectional design while theirs were a longitudinal one (Hiar et al. 2016; Kounou et al. 2017), and we used WHOQOL - BREF while Hiar et al. (2016) employ ed different instruments to assess the quality of life.

Possible limitations of this study include cross -sectional design , relatively small sample size of tertiar y center outpatients - increasin g the probability of Berkson `s bias (Berkson 1946) and recall bias.

Conclusions Peritraumatic tonic immobility is related to poor quality of life, adding new insights about the relationship between this immobility reaction and PTSD outcomes. Further research concerning QOL , peritraumatic reactions , and psychopathology is crucial . Longitudinal studies are necessary to investigate the

main determinants of the relationship between quality of life and different variables: distinct types of trauma tic event s, peritraumatic reactions , PTSD development and severity , and treatmen t response . Understanding these associations could inform the development of better assessment, prevention , and treatment strategies , also providing the legal system with conceptual tools to handle cases related to interpersonal violence.

Apesar de ainda negligenciada em humanos , a imobilidade tônica é um dos mais tí picos e prevalentes fen ômenos relacionados ao T EPT (KALAF et al., 2015; HAGEN AARS, 2016; MÖLLER ; SÖNDERGAARD ; HELSTRÖM, 2017 ). Pode ser considera da um marc ador de intensida de do medo e percepção de ameaça à sobrevivência , fazendo par te da cascata defensiva (CANTOR, 2009 ; BRACHA, 2004; FRAGKAKI et al., 2016 ). Tradi cionalmente estudada como um fenômeno peritraum ático, recentemente a IT pós-traumátic a tem sido associada à gravidade e cronicida de dos sinto mas do TEPT (DE KLEINE ; HAGENA ARS; VAN MINNE N, Considerando a relação entre gravidade , pior progn óstico e má resposta terapêutica no TEPT com uma maior intensidade de IT, é possíve l que haja u m subtipo de TEPT relacionado à IT , assim c omo foi proposto o subtipo dissociativo de TEPT (LANIUS et al., 2010). Mais estudos explorando os seus correlatos clínicos e neurobiol ógicos s ão necessá rios para i dentifica r o pa pel da IT peritraum ática e pós - traumatic a no TEPT e em outros desfechos clínicos , incluindo a qualid ade de vida . A ampliação do conh eciment o sobre o fenômeno de imobilidade tônica em humanos poderá contribuir para melhores estraté gias de ava liação, p revenção e tratamento do TEPT . Isso tem e speci al relevância no trauma sexual , tipo de evento traumático mais correla cionado com a IT. Os desfe chos clínicos e jurídicos são influenciados não s ó pela própri a especi ficidade da violência se xual, mas pe la resposta de imobilidade durante o evento traum ático .

Baseado em uma re visão integrativa da literatura sobre a imobilidade tônica induzida pelo estupro , esse estu do sinteti zou os principais conhecimentos d e pesquisas prévias, fornecendo subsídios para : 1) atualiz ação de práticas clínicas no campo da saúde ment al, incluindo a elaboração de programas de prevenção , psicoeducação e redução do estigma ; 2) investigação c línica sistemática da presença de IT em vítimas de violência sex ual e outro s tipos de eventos t raum áticos; 3) entendimento do con ceito d e IT para ape rfeiçoamento das práticas jurídicas relacionad as à violência se xual, incluindo o combate à revitimizaç ão.
